item.title: The long view of self-driving cars
item.description: Shortsighted special interests aim to preserve some jobs at the expense of saving lives on the road.

item.title: Presidents’ Day doesn’t exist
item.description: Plus, readers on saving historical art, climate change and the ‘endangerment finding.’

item.title: Mamdani meets economic reality
item.description: Now that he’s paying the bills, the mayor realizes a rental assistance program he promoted isn’t workable.

item.title: New START wasn’t a silver bullet, but it helped keep the world safe
item.description: Nuclear arms treaties have helped avoid a new arms race.

item.title: In defense of trolling
item.description: Saucy and provocative thoughts on the internet won’t ignite the apocalypse.

item.title: Trump’s death-row revenge gambit hits a judicial snag
item.description: The president uses blunt executive power to punish beneficiaries of Biden-commuted sentences.

item.title: Is Europe beginning to admit it has a problem?
item.description: Attacks on business by member states speak louder than the words of leaders at a summit.

item.title: Statism comes for social media
item.description: Russia undercuts WhatsApp and Telegram to push a government-created alternative.

item.title: Dr. Oz has a point about retirement
item.description: Spending healthy years in idleness isn’t good for you.

item.title: America’s nuclear future
item.description: The country can’t compete on AI without a truly all-the-above energy policy.

item.title: Alex Murdaugh’s murder appeal could hang on a silenced juror
item.description: Bizarre misconduct haunts the case of a prominent lawyer who killed his wife and son.

item.title: How a filmmaking revolution sparked the slow march to YouTube
item.description: I love movies, particularly the 1970s Hollywood classics. Why did I stop watching?

item.title: Dating is a market. Here's how to hack it.
item.description:
Want to win the dating game? Turns out business school has the playbook. Host Megan McArdle breaks down romance through Econ 101: addressable market, signaling, specialty products and sunk costs.
Whether you’re single, swiping or settled down, this episode will reshape how you think about love and commitment. Because in relationships, the fundamentals still matter — and sometimes it pays to think like a market participant.

item.title: Does your wedding have the union label?
item.description: Unite Here could be checking your website to make sure and bullying you if it doesn’t.

item.title: Another government sop to an ailing industry
item.description: An executive order requiring the military to purchase coal puts politics over the free market.

item.title: The unlucky truth about love
item.description: Governments are trying and failing to increase birth rates.
